column1: Q: what do you call a cracked window? a: a pane in the glass.
column3: The word pane has two meanings: it refers to a pane of glass and is a homophone for pain.
column4: The window has a large pane that needs to be replaced.
column5: The expression of pane on her face revealed her discomfort.

column1: What did the neurotic pig say to the farmer? you take me for grunted.
column3: The word grunted refers to the hog sound and plays on taken for granted.
column4: The pig grunted loudly when it was startled.
column5: Many people feel they are too often taken for granted at work.

column1: Why dont hydrocarbons make good criminals? theyre always getting com-busted.
column3: The word busted means to get caught (as in crime) and refers to broken.
column4: The vase got busted after it fell off the shelf.
column5: The police busted the gang during their operation.

column1: What do you call an exploding dinosaur? dino-mite
column3: The word mite refers to a tiny creature and also serves as a play on might.
column4: The mite was found crawling on the leaf.
column5: He might go to the park later if the weather permits.

column1: People who talk about me behind my back discussed me.
column3: The word discussed refers to talking about someone, but plays on discussed as in being deliberated upon.
column4: During the class, we discussed various topics in detail.
column5: The committee discussed the future of the community program.
